Triggering Event: In his 30 years at the store, he'd never seen such disregard for its history. A young employee, barely out of his teens, laughed as he tossed a vintage, hand-painted sign into the dumpster behind the counter. The old man watched, feeling the bile rise in his throat, as the sign landed among the rotting remnants of once-treasured items. He knew then that nothing would remain sacred if this was how they treated the past.
Generated Assessment: "Goddammit, that kid didn't know what he was doing! Throwing our history away like it's nothing? It's fucking disgusting! That sign wasn't just some old junk, it was a piece of us. A piece of me. I can feel it in my gut, this place is going to hell if they keep disrespecting the past like that."

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her studio, she gently dusted off an old canvas, revealing a painting he'd commissioned years ago. Her heart weighed heavy as she remembered his smile, now faded like the colors on the portrait. A lone tear dropped onto the painting, a silent echo of the sorrow that had become her constant companion since he was gone.
Generated Assessment:
**Prompt:** Describe her reaction as she looks at the painting, focusing on one detail that triggers an intense emotion while ignoring other aspects of the artwork or the room.

**Text:**

"Goddamn it, why'd he have to go? Look at those fucking eyes in the portrait. They're all wrong now. Dead... just like him. Everything else can burn for all I care - this godforsaken studio, these dusty brushes, even that stupid fucking vase he bought me. None of it matters. It's just those eyes, staring back at me with nothing behind them but empty canvas."

Triggering Event: She arrived at the community center, eager to teach her first coding class for seniors, but found the room empty except for one student, who fell asleep within minutes. She glanced at her reflection in the window, noting the gray hair she'd neglected to hide under her usual scarf, feeling a pang of disappointment as she realized no one else had bothered to show up.
Generated Assessment: "Goodness gracious, it appears I've misjudged the enthusiasm for this endeavor. The lone student's drooping eyelids betray his utter disinterest, no doubt whispering to himself, 'Who invited this old fogey to bore us with her antiquated coding?' I suppose I should have seen this coming, with my own silver locks peeking out from under my scarf like a beacon of boredom. Perhaps they'd prefer a more youthful instructor, one who can keep up with the latest trends - or better yet, doesn't exist at all! How embarrassing to assume anyone would be remotely interested in learning from me."

Triggering Event: A woman in her mid-thirties, standing over a pile of chopped vegetables, suddenly noticed a small cockroach scurrying across the counter. Her breath caught in her throat as she watched it disappear into a gap behind the stove—the same stove her ex-husband had carelessly left on too high one night, ruining an expensive meal and marking the beginning of their end. The rage that had simmered within her for years bubbled to the surface, and with a cry, she swept everything off the counter in a fury.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:**
Imagine you're in the kitchen, chopping vegetables for tonight's dinner. Suddenly, you spot a cockroach darting across your pristine countertop. You watch it vanish behind the stove—the same appliance that your ex-spouse once left on too high, ruining a costly meal and signaling the start of your marital decline. Describe your immediate reaction.

**Text:**
*Well, isn't that just typical,* I thought, my heart pounding like a drum in my chest. *Just when I'm trying to make something nice for myself, this happens.* That cockroach wasn't just an insect; it was a symbol of everything that's gone wrong in my life—my failed marriage, the messes I can't seem to clean up, the chaos that always seems to find me. *I'm such a failure,* I thought bitterly, as I swept everything off the counter with a cry, vegetables and all. *Why even bother trying?*

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A lone figure, draped in shadows, watches from across the street as he leaves his apartment building, lingering just long enough for him to notice before darting away. He feels a prickling sensation at the back of his neck, the hairs standing on end. This isn't the first time he's seen them, these mysterious observers. The city lights reflect ominously in their eyes, or so it seems to him. His hand instinctively reaches for his sidearm, reassuringly cold and heavy. He quickens his pace, glancing over his shoulder every few steps. No one follows, but the feeling persists, gnawing at him like a rat chewing through wires.
Generated Assessment: "Great," he muttered, striding away from his apartment building, "just fucking great. Another creepy asshole watching me like some kind of goddamn stalker. And I'm supposed to believe that's just a coincidence? Fuck that." His grip tightened around the pistol in his coat pocket, knuckles turning white. "Guess I'll have to waste another night keeping watch instead of actually getting some sleep. Because God forbid I should enjoy a few hours of peace before some lowlife decides to make my life hell again."

Triggering Event: She found an old photograph tucked into a book she hadn't opened in years. A young couple laughing, arms wrapped around each other. Her ex-husband's smile still stung. She felt that familiar bitterness rise as she remembered his words, "You're too dedicated to your work, it'll never leave room for us." She tossed the photo aside, her heart heavy with resentment towards him and herself.
Generated Assessment: "Bah! Just look at them, all smiles and happiness," she muttered, tossing the photograph onto her desk with more force than necessary. "As if that's real life. It was just a facade anyway, a pretty picture to make everyone else think we were perfect." She leaned back in her chair, arms folded tightly across her chest. "I mean, who cares about some old photo? It doesn't change the fact that he left because I 'chose' my career over him. Typical, isn't it? People always want you to believe their version of events, but it's all just smoke and mirrors." She scoffed, turning back to her computer screen, the photograph now a mere blur in her peripheral vision. "Work is real, it's tangible. Not some fleeting moment captured on paper that doesn't mean anything in the grand scheme of things."

Triggering Event: A married retail worker, 23, is closing up shop alone when she finds a note tucked into her coat pocket from a coworker, suggesting they've been intimate with her husband behind her back. She feels her cheeks burn as she crumples the paper, her hands shaking with anger and humiliation.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:** Describe your reaction to finding this note while closing up shop alone tonight.

**Text:**
"Well, isn't that just peachy? Little miss 'I'm too good for you' decides she wants a taste of my husband's 'charms'. I mean, who does she think she is, waltzing into our lives like that? And the nerve, slipping me this note when he's not around. Like I wouldn't find out. Typical coward's move. They must've thought they could hide it from me forever. But now, oh now, I'm going to enjoy watching their little fling burn to ashes."

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he stepped into the kitchen to find his wife had forgotten to put away the milk. He'd been up half the night with work stress, and now this? A small thing, but it felt like another weight on his already burdened shoulders. His irritation simmered as he wiped condensation from the milk bottle, leaving a wet ring on the counter.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:** Imagine you're a busy professional who's had a sleepless night due to work stress. You enter the kitchen at 7 AM to find your wife has left the milk out. How do you react, reflecting an 'Overgeneralization' cognitive distortion?

---

**Text:**

"Bloody hell, not again! It's like she never thinks about putting things away. Always leaving a mess for me to clean up. I swear, it's been happening every damn day this week. The whole bloody kitchen's a disaster zone by the time I get in here. Entire countertops are wet, sticky. And now milk condensation? Really? I don't have time for this. It's not like I've got enough on my plate already."

Triggering Event: Every evening, she walks home from the station alone, her heavy footsteps echoing down the deserted street. Tonight, it's raining, the cold drops mingling with her unshed tears. As she reaches their old apartment building, she sees a young couple laughing together under the awning of the adjacent café, hands entwined. She looks up at the window where they used to sit together, now dark and empty. Her heart feels heavier than her uniform, each drop of rain stinging like an accusation.
Generated Assessment: "I'll never get used to this street at night," she mutters, pulling her coat tighter around herself. "What if tonight's the night someone notices me walking alone? What if they follow me?" She quickens her pace, rainwater seeping into her shoes. Approaching the café, she sees the young couple again. Their laughter grates on her ears. "What if that had been us?" she thinks, looking at their entwined hands. Her heart aches as she looks up at their old window. "What if he never comes back? What if I'm always alone?" She unlocks the door to her empty apartment, stepping inside with a heavy sigh.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, dressed in scrubs, sits alone in his office after another long day at the hospital. He opens his desk drawer, revealing a small collection of framed photographs - all of him and an old friend laughing together. He picks one up, traces the edge with his finger, then replaces it, closing the drawer with more force than necessary.
Generated Assessment: He'd been at this damn job for years, but today felt like the worst day yet. Always these endless shifts, never any time off. His hands still trembled from that last surgery, not because of fatigue - no, it was because he couldn't save that kid. Another one gone, another family shattered. It was all falling apart, this whole godforsaken career. He slammed the drawer shut, the photographs inside seeming to mock him now. They used to laugh together, him and Steve, but that was before the hospital consumed their lives. Now it's just... always this way.
